intro: Sebastiania corniculata var. intercedens, commonly known as the red-berried sebastiania, is a species of flowering plant in the family Euphorbiaceae. It is native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America, where it thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. The plant is characterized by its striking red, fleshy berries that remain on the plant throughout the year. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a waxy coating, while the stems are succulent and can store water. This variant is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its vibrant fruit and unique appearance.
